cst300.courseDesc: This course is designed to assist students in planning their future professions. It is goal oriented, focusing on personal and professional goals, while also analyzing ethics and other important social aspects of the tech field. There are two major essays in the course, as well as two video presentations that are given towards the end of the course. Attached below is one of my essays, the industry analysis paper.

0.name: Industry Analysis Essay
0.desc: This essay was beneficial as it gave me the opportunity to research the jobs and economy of the gaming industry, with a focus on a very interesting company.

1.name: Ethics Argument Essay
1.desc: The other major paper in this course was the ethics argument essay, in which an argument is made for the punishment of individuals who download pirated media.

2.name: Future of Computer Science Education
2.desc: The team I worked with in this course presented a video about computer science education in which we researched past, present, and future trends in computer science education.
2.mediaHTML: <embed width='560' height='315' src='https://www.youtube.com/embed/Fqy0tga9tYI' title='YouTube video player' frameborder='0' allow='accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture' allowfullscreen></embed>

cst338.courseDesc: CST 338 teaches students how to develop large programs using object-oriented programming, teaches about the software life cycle, and provides and introduction to GUI development.

0.name: Card Combat
0.desc: Course Final Project. This was a card game developed in Java using the Swing UI, with all UI elements hard coded rather than using a visual editor. This game utilized the Model-View-Controller method.

1.name: Course Catalog - Simple Android App
1.desc: This simple Android application was a demonstration of mobile development basics using Android Studio.

cst363.courseDesc: This course provides balanced coverage of database use and design,focusing on relational databases. Students will learn to design relational schemas, write SQL queries, access a DB programmatically,and perform database administration. Students will gain a working knowledge of the algorithms and data structures used in query evaluation and transaction processing. Students will also learn to apply newer database technologies such as XML, NoSQL, and Hadoop.

0.name: Project 1 - Database Design
0.desc: Team Project. Team created a database system for a pharmacy chain. This was a reasonably complex database with 9 tables with multiple foreign keys and relationships. The project asked as to solve multiple problems using SQL queries.

1.name: Project 2 - Web App and JDBC SQL
1.desc: Implements a Spring Boot server based on the database from Project 1. Allows users to create a new prescription, fill prescriptions, and view FDA drug usage reports.
1.mediaHTML: <embed src='media/cst363_project2_1.png' width='25%'></embed><embed src='media/cst363_project2_2.png' width='25%'></embed><embed src='media/cst363_project2_3.png' width='25%'></embed><embed src='media/cst363_project2_4.png' width='25%'></embed>

cst334.courseDesc: Students in this course will learn about the use and design of modern operating systems, focusing on Linux. On the “use” side, students will learn the Linux command line, to write shell scripts, and to build programs with GNU utilities like awk, sed, and make. On the “design” side, students will develop a deep understanding of process management, memory management, file systems, and concurrency, and how they apply to modern technologies like virtualization and cloud computing. This course focused primarily on theory, so there were not any large projects. Instead, labs will be presented as proof of work.

0.name: Lab 5: Developing multi-threaded applications
0.desc: Lab demonstrating multithreaded programming to perform matrix multiplication in C.

1.name: Lab 6: Synchronization using semaphores
1.desc: Lab demonstrating the use of semaphores to solve the producer-consumer problem.

cst311.courseDesc: Survey of Telecomm and Data Comm Technology Fundamentals, Local Area Network, Wide Area Network, Internet and internet working protocols including TCP/IP, network security and performance, emerging industry trends such as voice over the network and high speed networking.

1.name: TCP Client-Server
1.desc: Program in python with which TCP clients and a server machine communicate using mininet.

0.name: UDP Pinger
0.desc: Learn about socket programming in Python by sending and receiving datagram packets through UDP

cst336.courseDesc: Provides students with dynamic web application development skills, focusing on the integration of server-side programming, database connectivity, and client-side scripting. Coverage includes the Internet architecture, responsive design, RESTful web services, and Web APIs.

0.name: Random Anime Picker
0.desc: Site that generates a random anime to watch from an external API based on user preference. Uses JQuery to generate page elements.

1.name: Sushi On A Roll | Online Food Ordering
1.desc: Website which allows users to order food from a menu populated via a local API which grabs menu items from a MySQL database. The user creates an account with a password encrypted with bcrypt. A team project with 3 other members, I handled the creation and population of the menu by writing an API.

cst462.longName: CST 462S - Race, Gender, Class in the Digital World
cst462.courseDesc: Provides students with key knowledge of race, gender, class and social justice especially in relation to technology in today's digital world. Students challenge the barriers of expertise, gender, race, class, and location that restrict wider access to and understanding of the production and usage of new technologies. Students will engage in a practical experience in the community via their service placements, which will provide depth and context for considering questions of justice, equality, social responsibilities and the complexities of technology and its societal impact. The course uses scenario based approach combining presentations, discussions, and reflections to allow students explore the relationship between critical reflection and action on the topics mentioned above.

0.name: Research Paper
0.desc: Research project which surveys the correlation between internet access and quality of education. Interviews conducted with multiple educators to gather first hand experiences.

1.name: Service Learning
1.desc: Served as a volunteer for the IT Department at Mountains Community Hospital performing simple IT maintenance tasks.

cst328.courseDesc: A survey course that combines the study of technology, design and aesthetic principles as they apply to twenty-first century visual media. Students learn how fundamental concepts of art and design apply to a broad range of commercial, expressive and entertainment forms. Students also study the democratization of the creative process through digital media, using current technology to produce sophisticated and expressive examples of personal digital creativity.

0.name: App Design Prototype
0.desc: Design concept for an iPhone app created with Illustrator and Photoshop
0.mediaHTML: <embed src=media/cst328_project1_1.jpg width=33%></embed><embed src=media/cst328_project1_2.jpg width=33%></embed><embed src=media/cst328_project1_3.jpg width=33%></embed>

1.name: Cryptocurrency Trading App Design Prototype
1.desc: Design concept for a mobile app for trading cryptocurrency assets. Used Illustrator, Photoshop, and XD

cst370.longName: CST 370 - Design and Analysis of Algorithms
cst370.courseDesc: Students learn important data structures in computer science and acquire fundamental algorithm design techniques to get the efficient solutions to several computing problems from various disciplines. Topics include the analysis of algorithm efficiency, hash, heap, graph, tree, sorting and searching, brute force, divide-and-conquer, decrease-and-conquer, transform-and-conquer, dynamic programming, and greedy programming.

0.name: Merge sort and Quick sort comparison
0.desc: Homework assignment which implements merge sort and quick sort in Java, and compares the execution speed on large sets of integers.

1.name: Robot Coin Collector
1.desc: Homework which solves the robot coin collector problem using dynamic programming

2.name: Heap Operations
2.desc: Constructs a heap using inputted integers, and allows for various operations such as inserting, removing, and displaying values

cst383.courseDesc: In data science, data analysis and machine learning techniques are applied to visualize data, understand trends, and make predictions. In this course students will learn how to obtain data, preprocess it, apply machine learning methods, and visualize the results. A student who completes the course will have enough theoretical knowledge, and enough skill with modern statistical programming languages and their libraries, to define and perform complete data science projects.

0.name: Project - Predicting Bitcoin Price
0.desc: Using Pandas, Numpy, Seaborn, and Scikit-Learn, my team created a machine learning model which predicts the price of bitcoin using 30 days of averaged price data, using an API.

1.name: Campaign Exploration
1.desc: Homework assignment which demonstrates data processing and visualization using Pandas and Seaborn

cst329.courseDesc: In this course students learn to develop skill in using logic to describe and assess arguments. Students will learn to write formulas in propositional and first-order logic, and more importantly, to write and check proofs. Students will also learn to write formulas in three-valued and modal logic, know how to choose an appropriate logic, and understand the limitations of logic in capturing human reasoning.

0.name: Propositional Proofs
0.desc: Some examples of proofs done in the course using propositional logic.
0.mediaHTML: <embed src=media/cst329_proof_2.png width=33%></embed><embed src=media/cst329_proof_1.png width=33%></embed><embed src=media/cst329_proof_3.png width=33%></embed>

1.name: First Order Proofs
1.desc: Some examples of proofs done in the course using first order logic.
1.mediaHTML: <embed src=media/cst329_proof_4.png width=33%></embed><embed src=media/cst329_proof_5.png width=33%></embed><embed src=media/cst329_proof_6.png width=33%></embed>

0.name: Registration Service
0.desc: Developed a web service using microservice architecture that allows school administrators to add and modify students in a database. Implemented testing using JUnit and Selenium to test the front and back ends. Collaborated with teammate to communicate with a corresponding registration service using a message queue. This project was cumulative throughout the course and represents a large amount of the course work done.

cst499.courseDesc: Students will work on a project in large groups (up to 5 students in each group), developing requirements specification, a solution plan followed by design and implementation of the solution. The problem statement for the projects will be selected by the faculty. Faculty will also play the role of a project manager directing the schedule and deliverables for these projects.

0.name: Capstone Proposal
0.desc: Proposal Submitted to CSUMB faculty before course to outline planned work for capstone.

1.name: Capstone Report
1.desc: Report on work submitted to faculty detailing work done in capstone.

2.name: Capstone Video
2.desc: Video created for festival demonstrating project capabilities.
